Few thoughts:

1) The criticism around Bitcoin/Ethereum development not being "decentralized" enough may not have merit. Perhaps this is a strength and not a weakness. Open to hearing counter-arguments.

2) Does the same 80/20 dynamic hold for closed organizations?

1122684103478767617.text:
You can see the same 80/20 dynamic at play with open-source projects like Bitcoin and Ethereum. As well as in non-crypto projects like React: 

https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/graphs/contributors …
https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/graphs/contributors …
https://github.com/facebook/react/graphs/contributors …pic.twitter.com/d9j6BENHCG

1122684102803464192.text:
The paper argues otherwise and claims that:

1) Majority of open-source projects are in fact "hero" projects.
2) The commits from “hero developers” result in far fewer bugs than other developers.

Thus, having "heroes" in projects significantly improves code quality.

1122684102170140672.text:
Just read a fascinating study on "Why Software Projects need Heroes".

A “hero” project is where 80% of the contributions are made by the 20% of the developers.

It's often thought that these projects should be deprecated b/c they cause bottlenecks in development & communication.

1116352641808789509.text:
Instead, it’s an opportunity for both sides to think critically about a given topic and formulate a more complete picture on the matter.

In this sense, a debate is actually about opposing sides working together to show each other a different perspective.

1116352640818925569.text:
In building TruStory, I’ve discovered that debating is the best way to seek and learn the truth.

Contrary to what the internet thinks, the purpose of a debate isn’t to be deemed right or wrong.

1116352639925514243.text:
“Let’s fight” has left no room for “Let’s explore this idea together.”

It’s no wonder most of us don’t want to “debate” — who wants to be thrown into the ringer & get publicly shamed if others don’t agree with their opinions?

It shouldn’t be this way. And it doesn’t have to be.

1116352638994399238.text:
As a result, internet debates have become a race to react rather than respond. 

Instead of being opportunities for meaningful discussion, they’ve become word wars to win.

Argumentative attitudes have replaced our willingness to understand different perspectives.

1116352638117761024.text:
Traditional media promotes clickbait and hot takes. And Twitter just happens to be a place where you can see all this in action in real-time.  

So, unsurprisingly, when most of us hear the word “debate,” our minds hear the word “fight.”

1116352637211820032.text:
On the internet, and especially in the crypto world, there’s a high priority placed on being open and transparent. Yet, both are plagued with closed-mindedness and toxicity. 

Social networks today incentivize outrage, echo chambers, and fragmented conversation.

1116352636465192960.text:
The problem with the internet is not lack of truth; it’s lack of willingness to have a healthy conversation. 

But wait, it gets weirder.

1116352635567628288.text:
If I asked you to publicly debate me on a topic you’re an expert in, would you say “yes”?

99% of you would say “NO”

That's because Internet debates are fights, not debates.

1116352634707828737.text:
When you participate in a Twitter debate, you’ve already lost. 

But why is this? 

To answer this, let’s put Twitter aside for a moment and pivot to a topic I’m obsessed with: Debate.

1116352633801805824.text:
You honestly have better odds at winning the lottery, going to Mars, or walking on water.

Twitter debates are a lot like Game of Thrones — except they’re even more vicious. And there’s no way to win.

1112509752490098688.text:
But of course, having a leader is seen as "bad" in Crypto. How dare we have a leader? 

So what's the solution?

I'm excited to talk through this in-depth tomorrow. See you at 11a PST.

1112509751412187136.text:
Without those, you don't have a community.

Communities don't form norms by accident. They must be intentionally defined. These usually get defined by leadership. When you go full leader-less before these norms are defined, you end up with a bunch of people who are lost / stuck.

1112509750166470656.text: I concluded that the Ethereum community needs to figure out what its shared social & political values are. Without shared social and political norms, we can’t expect people to magically agree on what needs to be done. Open communities form around shared norms.

1112509748731994112.text: This is a topic I've spent a lot of time thinking about in the past after the drama around the Parity bug, and I gave a presentation last May at Edcon where I highlighted my findings:https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1glfZTTyrQUU_FAzT36PyJup1IR0jr0q5x1Aqie0Pd84/edit?usp=sharing …

1032681707487428608.text: IMO, that is what the newer consensus protocols like Proof-of-Stake (e.g. Tendermint, Capser), Thunderalla, Ouroboros Paxos, Honeybadger, DFINITY, Avalanche, etc. are aiming to do.

1032681706677915650.text: If we can figure out other ways to steer a distributed network of nodes to agree on the same value consistently such that the transaction log eventually reaches an irreversible state, then why not try?

1032681705931386881.text: But this doesn't mean that we can't design consensus protocols that don't need the physical expenditure of energy to create an immutable ledger. The immutability comes from the fact that the state is irreversible, and not the fact that energy was expended.

1032681705193127937.text: It assumes an honest majority to expend computational effort, rather than every single node agreeing on a value. It was simple to understand. It was easily deployable. And WALA, that's why we have Bitcoin.

1032681704270360576.text: The brilliance of Nakamoto Consensus was making it probabilistic. Instead of every node agreeing on a value, *f(x)* worked such that all of the nodes agree on the probability of the value being correct.

1032681703540633600.text: In traditional consensus, f(x) was defined such that all nodes had to communicate and agree on a value. Too complex. Doesn't scale. Doesn't work in open, permissionless systems where anyone can join the network at any time.

1032681702127067136.text: In other words, a set of distributed computers are trying to agree on the output of every transaction in order to maintain a consistent transaction log across every computer in the system.

1032681701367939072.text: Transactions → f(x) → Replicated transaction log (i.e. “immutable ledger”), where f(x) is the consensus algorithm.

Even simply framing it as, "I'd love to pick your brain about X. I'm working on Y and I'm trying to learn more about X and you seem like a great person to bounce ideas off of." 

This gives the other person enough context to either choose to help, or to not help.

935550670962167809.text: My main point is that the easier you make it for the other person to know how they can help you, the more likely you'll get a response. If it's left unclear, then harder to get a yes.

935550435418456064.text:
For example, being asked to "pick your brain about blockchain". 

Well, where do we even start? Do we want to go through all of blockchain in 30 minutes? Is there something more specific you're working on or look at that I can help with and provide valuable insight for?

935550322126176256.text:
It's more about how to frame the question to make it easier for the other person to 

1) Know whether they can help you.
2) Know whether they want to help you.

935550224855994368.text: 1. This tweet was not necessarily about providing "free" help or consulting. I frankly love sharing all my knowledge, and that's why I write lots of blogs post, give lots of conference talks, and do lots of mentee 1:1s, for free.https://twitter.com/iam_preethi/status/935366112597876736 …

935366112597876736.text:
Asking to "pick your brain" has become somewhat vexing to me. 

Why? Because it signals laziness. The best & quickest way to get help from someone (I think) is to be specific & know (somewhat) what you want to ask. Asking to pick their brain is vague & unclear.

Agree? Disagree?
